pr_title: Fix bugs and clean up code

timeline.bodyText:
I know why you did this, but I don't feel that this is appropriately fixing it. The reason why it failed is that the subscriber is called immediately during the subscribe. Which I think we do want, since that will immediately cause the service to restart and wait for the dependency to come up. With the change that you've made it will not do this; instead it would need the dependency to change state again before triggering this handling.
I think one potential fix is to overload dependencyReady with an extra parameter for the startWhen state. Alternatively, just remove the start when state because I think we've been talking about getting rid of it for a while.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: We're not using startWhen? Do we allow specify dependency on different states?
replies.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: It is allowed, but I know that Shirley has talked about removing it. We're not really using it at this time. All startWhen is just Running.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Given that we'll want hot pluggability, maybe instead you should change the signature to take a DependencyInfo, that way you can pass it in directly instead of reading it from the dependency map since it doesn't exist at that point.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I modified to pass in the startWhen.
replies.author: fengwang666

timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: Can this be scoped down from throwable? Maybe IOException?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: This will be revisited again. A lot of them haven't been cleaned up yet.
replies.author: fengwang666

timeline.bodyText: This can be tricky. since this subscriber is created and added only once, if you update the same dependency with a different startWhen, it will not update the subscriber
timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: How about just removing the startWhen field?
replies.author: fengwang666

timeline.bodyText: Would it be crazy to just do this outside of the compute so that the value is in the map when dependencyRead() tries to look it up?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Surely it will work, but is that much better than the current way? What's the benefit?
replies.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: Just that passing everything through feels a bit ugly, especially when we need more than just the startWhen state.
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure if I completely get what you propose. If we try to construct the DependencyInfo outside and put it to dependencies, we can only construct it partially without the subscriber field and later we need to set the subscriber field. It's not ideal either.
replies.author: fengwang666

timeline.message: address comments not to create multiple subscribers for a dependency

timeline.bodyText: Why do we want to resubscribe all the time? I believe we ought to be using computeIfAbsent and then just subscribing once.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: If startWhenState is updated, don't we need to create a different subscriber?
replies.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: Oh, maybe. If the subscriber is pulling the startWhenState from the lambda's closure.
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: add ".log()" in the end. Also is it good to log the error and throw it at the same time?
timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: As I explained in the comment, since we're doing structure logging, I think it's better to log the error too so that if we going to use a tool to parse the log, the error log won't be lost.
replies.author: fengwang666

timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.bodyText: Curious, is it only available to Linux?
timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: It is available in some of the Windows that are posix-compliant. We'll need to revisit this when we're testing on Windows.
replies.author: fengwang666
